title: Restaurants finally forced to hand all tips to waiters - three years late
text:

Restaurants will be forced to hand over tips to staff - more than three years after the Tories first promised to crack down on abuses.

The new law in the Queen's Speech will force employers to pass on all gratuities in full and to share fairly any pooled tips.

The Tories first promised to tackle the injustice under then-business secretary Sajid Javid who ordered a two-month consultation ending on June 27, 2016.

Last summer Labour announced a policy of allowing workers to keep 100% of the tips they earn.

The government finally announced it would introduce new legislation to ban employers taking tips from staff last October at the Tory Party conference.

But Theresa May then failed to bring in the change during her time in office.

Today the Employment (Allocation of Tips) Bill also introduces a Code of Practice for restaurants, bars and cafes to make the system transparent.

Ten years ago, the Mirror launched our Fair Tips campaign with Unite the Union after a Pizza Express manager was sacked for revealing that the company kept 8% of tips paid by bank cards as an “administration fee”.

(Image: PA)

Our campaign persuaded the then-Labour government in 2008 to close a loophole which was allowing employers using tips to top up wages to the legal minimum wage.

It led to the drawing up of an industry Code of Best Practice.

But since it was only voluntary was widely ignored.

We have exposed how some restaurants force staff to pay out of their tips if a customer leaves without paying from their tips, others force staff to pay into a pot of tips - even if they haven't earned any - and others simply keep the service charge rather than passing it on to staff.

(Image: The Daily Mirror)

Last year staff at TGI Fridays staged the first restaurant strikes over tipping.

They walked out over a move by the chain giving 40% of the service charge to chefs and other back-of-house staff instead of giving them a pay increase.

It has cost waiters up to £250 a month and effectively making them subsidise the pay of colleagues.
description: The move in the 2019 Queen's Speech comes more than three years after the Tories first promised to clamp down on the unfair practise
